Not all of that sum is paid by the states, given the federal government\u0026rsquo;s contribution, but it is managed by the states. (Kaiser Family Foundation State Health Facts. Total Medicaid spending, FY 2016.)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e In an average-sized state, Medicaid directors are the single largest purchaser in the health sector, overseeing about $10 billion each year in payments to providers (roughly 17% of the state\u0026rsquo;s economy).\u003ca rel=\"#footnote2\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e2\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote2\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e2.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eMedicaid spending, including both the state and federal shares, is the overall funding that Medicaid agencies manage in their states. This spending accounts for an average of 29% of state budgets. (National Association of State Budget Officers. \u003cem\u003eState Expenditure Report.\u003c/em\u003e November 17, 2016.)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The agencies typically serve nearly one-quarter of their state\u0026rsquo;s population\u003ca rel=\"#footnote3\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e3\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote3\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e3.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eKaiser Family Foundation. Medicaid pocket primer. January 3, 2017.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e and, in our experience, procure the largest IT infrastructure projects in state government.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRecently, demands on state Medicaid agencies have grown. Increasingly, Medicaid agencies are playing a multi-part role, fulfilling their traditional responsibilities (i.e., payer-purchaser, operator) and taking on new ones (i.e., market shaper and innovator). And while they are doing this, the agencies must address an array of competing priorities, as well as uncertainty about future funding levels. To perform well in these new roles, the agencies must develop new, next-generation capabilities so they can address the needs of their state\u0026rsquo;s citizens\u0026mdash;even those not enrolled in Medicaid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe the roles played by state Medicaid agencies will continue to evolve, but the agencies\u0026mdash;in conjunction with the state government leaders they work with\u0026mdash;can choose their strategic path forward (primarily, the extent to which they want to be market shapers). Those that pursue this path aggressively will be the first of their peers to evolve into a Medicaid Agency of the Future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs we discuss below, all state Medicaid agencies will need to strengthen their capabilities if they are to meet the demands of the future\u0026mdash;an issue that has important implications not only for the agencies themselves but also for state government leaders, managed care organizations (MCOs), local providers, and others. However, agencies focused on becoming market shapers will need to double down on capability building if they want to succeed on their chosen path.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote4\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e4\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote4\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e4.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eOur recommendations apply regardless of the model of agency (i.e., one state agency overseeing Medicaid or many). In either case, activities need to be well coordinated and well executed.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTrends shaping Medicaid\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA number of trends are shaping what Medicaid agencies need to do to prioritize the direction of their efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSpending growth is putting pressure on state budgets.\u003c/strong\u003e Medicaid is putting continued cost pressure on state budgets. Program spending (including federal and state funding) increased from 20.5% of state budgets in 2008 to 29.0% in 2016.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote5\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e5\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote5\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e5.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eBetween 2015 and 2016 alone, state spending on Medicaid grew 6.9%, whereas overall state spending rose only 4.0%. (National Association of State Budget Officers. \u003cem\u003eState Expenditure Report.\u003c/em\u003e November 17, 2016.)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The continued increase in Medicaid spending could have funding implications for other state programs, such as elementary and higher education, public assistance, and transportation. The cost pressures resulting from Medicaid spending are expected to continue regardless of what, if any, changes are made at the federal level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMedicaid programs can lead to payment inno­vation.\u003c/strong\u003e As program costs have risen, Medicaid directors have increasingly tried to slow the medical cost trend. One lever available to them is transitioning from fee-for-service reimbursement to payment innovations that include meaningful levels of provider risk-sharing. New payment models that reward providers for delivering high-quality care at lower cost have been shown to improve care quality and reduce costs by 5% to 10% when rolled out across the full spending base.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote6\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e6\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote6\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e6.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003ePatient-Centered Primary Care Collaborative. \u003cem\u003eBenefits of Implementing the Primary Care Patient-Centered Medical Home: A Review of Cost \u0026amp; Quality Results, 2012.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cem\u003e In several states, Medicaid programs have led multi-payer efforts to achieve payment inno­vation across the state.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote7\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e7\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote7\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e7.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eFor example, Ohio has led multi-payer efforts for episodes of care, patient-centered medical homes, and behavioral health; the efforts have involved five Medicaid plans and four commercial payors (Ohio Department of Medicaid website on payment innovation). Tennessee has engaged both Medicaid and commercial payors on efforts around long-term services and supports, primary care transformation, and episodes of care (Division of TennCare website on the Tennessee Health Care Innovation Initiative).\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMedicaid plays an important role as both a payer and a convener.\u003c/strong\u003e In the aggregate, Medicaid is the country\u0026rsquo;s largest payer in terms of covered lives and, in many states, is the largest purchaser of healthcare ser­vices.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote8\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e8\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote8\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e8.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eKaiser Family Foundation. State Health Facts: Health insurance coverage of the total population. 2015.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Thus, Medicaid agencies are uniquely positioned to facilitate change. In addition, the agencies can often bring together multiple stakeholders to help align on improvements that would affect not only Medicaid but also the entire healthcare market.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRecognition of Medicaid members as consumers is increasing.\u003c/strong\u003e Some Medicaid agencies are beginning to approach Medicaid members as consumers. For example, they are offering members technological tools, such as apps and patient portals, that empower greater decision making (e.g., about choice of provider, care setting, or treatment). If well utilized, these tools can improve member experience and encourage higher-value care.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAwareness of social determinants is rising.\u003c/strong\u003e Increasingly, states are turning their attention to non-health factors, such as housing, education, and transportation, that influence Medicaid members\u0026rsquo; ability to maintain their health and adhere to treatment. Some programs are beginning to address these determinants head on (e.g., by providing housing or transportation vouchers). Experimentation in special needs care is underway. Integrated models typically deliver better quality and cost outcomes. For example, integrated behavioral and physical healthcare approaches for high-needs patients have been shown to reduce emergency department and inpatient visit spending by 10% to 25%.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote9\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e9\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote9\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e9.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eReiss-Brennan B et al. Association of integrated team-based care with health care quality, utilization, and cost. \u003cem\u003eJAMA\u003c/em\u003e. 2016;316(8):826-34.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The successes to date are paving the way for further innovation in other special needs areas.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAnalytics is playing an increasing role.\u003c/strong\u003e Advanced analytics and big data can help Medicaid and other public health officials better understand state needs, design programs, and target interventions to maximize the impact of limited funds. The emergence of new national data-sets, such as the Transformed Medicaid Statistical Information System (T-MSIS, which includes states\u0026rsquo; comprehensive claims and enrollment data) and CMS\u0026rsquo; online database of state waivers and state plan amendments, may enable states to draw on experiences elsewhere when designing new programs.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote10\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e10\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote10\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e10.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eInformation on all of the data-sets can be found on the Medicaid.gov web pages for:\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;Transformed Medicaid Statistical Information System (T-MSIS).\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;Medicaid state plan amendments.\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;State waivers list.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn short, state Medicaid agencies are facing an increasingly complex and difficult set of challenges at a time when the expectations of multiple stakeholders\u0026mdash;members, families, and advocates; providers and MCOs; the federal government, state leaders, and other state agencies\u0026mdash;are rising. If Medicaid agencies are to address these challenges successfully, the role they play must evolve.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIntroducing the Medicaid Agency of the Future\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the future, some state Medicaid agencies may opt to follow the path set by previous state leaders. In other cases, they may want to respond to the trends just discussed by taking the lead in transforming healthcare delivery in their programs and their states. These Agencies of the Future will have to be able to chart a strong strategic direction and execute the activities that follow both efficiently and effectively. To accomplish those goals, they will need to use a data-driven approach to program management, build new capabilities, and improve their organizational health (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAgencies that opt to follow a more traditional path would also benefit from strengthening their operational performance and organi­zational health, but the level of improvement needed is lower for them than for the Agencies of the Future. Both sets of agencies, however, will want to prioritize their strategic investments once they have chosen their path forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[[Exhibit Exhibit_1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eChart a strategic direction\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\nGiven the complex landscape, many state Medicaid agencies are struggling today to define their strategic priorities. Our ex­perience suggests that the agencies will be better able to develop a coherent approach to strategy if they consider the six dimensions described below.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough it may seem counterintuitive, many agencies may find it easier to establish priorities by \u0026ldquo;thinking bigger\u0026rdquo; about their scope. For example, they may want to pull in other groups or agencies to achieve common strategic objectives. Strategic collaboration can enable all parties to leverage economies of scale, make use of limited resources and specialized skills, and reduce the time frame between strategy and execution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStrengthen their approach to managed care.\u003c/strong\u003eToday, 39 states have transitioned, at least partially, to managed Medicaid, and nearly half of all Medicaid service-related spending is allotted to MCO capitation. As a result, one of the largest strategic levers state Medicaid agencies have at their disposal is transforming their approach to managed care. Some studies suggest that well-run managed care programs (in comparison with a fee-for-service model) can reduce healthcare service costs,\u003ca rel=\"#footnote11\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e11\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote11\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e11.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eAlthough the evidence supporting managed care use currently comes primarily from non-peer-reviewed studies, the evidence base is continuing to expand. The reports below provide a synthesis of the evidence:\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;Sparer M. \u003cem\u003eMedicaid Managed Care: Costs, Access and Quality of Care. \u003c/em\u003eRobert Wood Johnson Foundation. September 2012.\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;Lewin Group. \u003cem\u003eMedicaid Managed Care Cost Savings\u0026mdash;A Synthesis of 24 Studies.\u003c/em\u003e America\u0026rsquo;s Health Insurance Plans. Updated March 2009.\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;Duggan M, Hayford T. Has the shift to managed care reduced Medicaid expenditures? Evidence from state and local-level mandates. NBER Working Paper. July 2011.\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026ndash;The Menges Group. \u003cem\u003eProjected Savings of Medi­caid Capitated Care: National and State-by-State.\u003c/em\u003e October 2015.\u003cbr /\u003e\nSee also: Allison A, Lewis R, Ward T, Wynn B. Looking ahead in Medicaid: Options for states and implications for payors and providers. McKinsey white paper. May 2017.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e which underscores the importance of strengthening managed care program management. Our calculations suggest that each percentage point improvement in MCO cost performance would translate to more than $2.5 billion in efficiencies nationally. Thus, many state Medicaid agencies might be interested in moving away from transactional sourcing approaches when selecting MCOs, instead building toward an advanced collaborative approach in which the agencies and MCOs are true strategic partners (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[[Exhibit Exhibit_2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRedesign payment.\u003c/strong\u003e States are pursuing a range of payment innovations, including one-sided and two-sided risk sharing. State Medicaid agencies need to assess their readiness for these innovations and clarify the role they want to play. For example, do they want to allow MCOs to deploy payment innovations independently\u0026mdash;or be more prescriptive about what MCOs can do? Do they want to act on their own or collaborate with other organizations within their state?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEnhance their special needs strategy.\u003c/strong\u003e Today, nearly two-thirds of a typical Medicaid budget is spent on care for special needs populations,\u003ca rel=\"#footnote12\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e12\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote12\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e12.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eThese populations include individuals with behavioral health conditions or intellectual or developmental disabilities, as well as those in need of long-term services and supports.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e a proportion likely to grow in the future. Many of the organizations that provide services to those populations rely heavily on Medicaid funding. However, comparatively few of these organizations have been involved in the types of payment innovation that are being used increasingly with primary and acute care providers. A more strategic approach to care provision for the special needs populations could enable state Medicaid agencies to achieve better outcomes at the same or lower cost. Exhibit 3 shows some of the decisions the agencies would need to make when developing such a strategy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[[Exhibit Exhibit_3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMeasure public health return on investment (ROI).\u003c/strong\u003e It is becoming increasingly important for state Medicaid and other healthcare agencies to determine the ROI on the money they are spend­ing and identify opportunities to improve it. Although such calculations are difficult, they can be done. For example, we found that one public health agency had reduced its run-rate costs by 17% after shifting its investments toward primary prevention. Furthermore, estimating expected ROI can help state Medicaid agencies determine which programs to prioritize.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAssess provider market role.\u003c/strong\u003e Both state government leaders and Medicaid agencies should consider what role the state should play in providing certain services, especially those for special needs populations.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote13\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e13\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote13\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e13.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eSome states currently own nursing homes, psy­chiatric hospitals, and/or facilities for individuals with intellectual or developmental disabilities.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Either or both groups may want to investigate whether care quality might increase, and spending decrease, if some of the facilities providing those services were operated or owned by private organizations.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConsider interactions between Medicaid and other state healthcare markets.\u003c/strong\u003e States differ significantly in how they view their healthcare markets. Some states would like to include Medicaid with other efforts to improve healthcare access and delivery\u0026mdash;for example, by reducing churn between different types of coverage or gaining greater leverage for healthcare purchasing across state agencies. In these states, Medicaid agencies may want to play a leadership role (e.g., through 1332 waivers). Other states, however, may view the Medicaid market as a stand-alone entity and ask their Medicaid agencies to focus on core functions, such as determining eligibility and enrolling members. All states, however, should consider what impact their Medicaid programs are having on other state healthcare markets\u0026mdash;and on the participants who may move between these markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eExecute efficiency and effectively\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\nAs complexity increases, strong execution becomes even more important to ensure that state Medicaid agencies meet their goals. To determine where they most need to improve their capabilities, the agencies can create \u0026ldquo;from\u0026minus;to\u0026rdquo; maps to assess their ability to undertake the following activities:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStrengthen MCO rate setting and performance management.\u003c/strong\u003e Among the states that have at least partially transitioned to managed care, more than 20 MCO contracts are up for renewal within the next two years. We have found that a best-in-class approach to rate determination can unlock substantial value, which state Medicaid agencies can then spend on other priorities. The agencies may also benefit by studying some of the best-in-class contracting approaches used in other industries (e.g., the defense industry tightly links rewards and penalties to performance against quality and other contract measures).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo complement these efforts, many agencies would benefit from a comprehensive transparency strategy that includes public reporting of both MCO performance (assessed regularly) and contract-based performance incentives (Exhibit 4).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[[Exhibit Exhibit_4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHarness innovation.\u003c/strong\u003e Medicaid agencies\u0026mdash; especially those that aspire to become next-generation Agencies of the Future\u0026mdash;will need to innovate in a number of areas, including payment, benefits, and policies to promote efficiency. The Agencies of the Future will have the policy and execution backbone that will allow them to affect citizens beyond Medicaid enrollees, through efforts across lines of business. In many cases, these agencies will tackle previously intractable problems, such as the social determinants of health and the digitization of citizen services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlaying this leadership role will require new aspirations and a new level of supporting capabilities. Many states, including Ohio, Virginia, and Washington, have already created small teams focused on policy and program inno­vation in Medicaid; often, the efforts extend to integrated healthcare innovation across markets. Other states are likely to follow suit. Experimentation in multiple states makes it possible for all of them to identify and adopt the best innovations. Federally collected data-sets, including T-MSIS, are making it possible for state Medicaid agencies to compare their innovations against benchmarks from other states. However, data alone will not be enough; the agencies will need to begin acting today if they want to acquire a next-generation mind-set of leadership on behalf of a broad citizenry.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEnsure program integrity across the state and managed care.\u003c/strong\u003e State Medicaid agencies will also need to strengthen program integrity by putting greater focus on program and payment design, as well as the management of provider and member relationships. Enhanc­ing program integrity can, in our experience, reduce overall program costs by 1% to 2%, and sometimes more. Leading state Medicaid agencies have already established dedicated payment integrity units that prioritize opportunities based on impact, and track prevention and recovery efforts. For the Agencies of the Future, adequately addressing fraud, waste, and abuse will require a number of steps\u0026mdash;for example, ensuring senior leadership alignment on a broad aspiration; developing a clear strategy for value capture from MCOs and other vendors; and aligning appropriate resourcing, including people, knowledge, and technology.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImprove quality measurement.\u003c/strong\u003e Achieving meaningful rather than incremental improvements in care quality and outcomes requires planning and interagency coordination. Given that more than 600 nationally endorsed quality measures are currently available, monitoring can easily become inconsistent. State Medicaid agencies should select a consistent set of about 20 to 40 quality metrics that can be used in all parts of the program, including population health, payment innovation, and managed care initiatives.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImprove stakeholder engagement.\u003c/strong\u003eState Medi­caid agencies are increasingly interacting with an expanded array of stakeholders on an interconnected set of issues. In the past, community stakeholder engagement may have focused on getting input and buy-in, but today many agencies are looking to co-create programs with community groups (e.g., to address social determinants of health). The changing nature of these interactions may require the involvement of more senior leaders. For example, establishment of value-based payment models may require the joint efforts of a state\u0026rsquo;s Medicaid director, local hospital CEOs, and MCO executives. However, broad stakeholder engagement can sometimes slow the pace of change. State Medicaid agencies should therefore be purposeful about their approach to stakeholder engagement and partner selection to ensure that they can continue to push innovation forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSimplify member interface.\u003c/strong\u003eMedicaid member interfaces remain an important lever, parti­cularly for states with robust fee-for-service infrastructure. To ensure consistent member engagement, state Medicaid agencies should ensure that members have transparency into their choice of providers, payers, and programs, as well as the touch points needed to support those choices. For example, Colorado\u0026rsquo;s PEAK app enables fee-for-service Medicaid members to apply for benefits, determine eligibility, select facilities, and communicate with providers.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote14\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e14\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote14\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e14.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eColorado PEAK website and app.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e In addition, Medicaid agencies can encourage members to select value-based care models and, for instance, make sure they have materials appropriate for diverse cultural and linguistic audiences. Consumer engagement is often vital for supporting other levers, such as quality of care and personal responsibility.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMeasure to manage\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\nAs a growing amount of data becomes available and states develop increasingly aspirational strategies, state Medicaid agencies will need to develop more effective performance management approaches.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImprove data quality.\u003c/strong\u003e Data quality will likely be the backbone of all future activities. Thus, Medicaid agencies will have to determine and perhaps strengthen their data capabilities in a number of areas, including:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eData uniqueness (e.g., ensuring meaningful and comparable population identifiers)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eInternal consistency (e.g., resolving incomplete or overlapping program designations)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eField validity (e.g., correcting invalid national provider identification codes)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eData completeness and timeliness (e.g., ensuring linkage between professional and facility claims)\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eData correctness (e.g., ensuring consistent calculation of such measures as emergency department utilization or generic prescription rates)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDeploy advanced analytics.\u003c/strong\u003eIn the future, Medicaid agencies will benefit from the ability to deploy advanced analytic approaches that blend best-in-class analysis with distinctive visualization. Today, many state Medicaid lead­ers use static data to set policy, but the Agency of the Future will employ dynamic forecasting and use data to introduce real-time care interventions, mirroring innovations already achieved in other industries. (The specific analytic focus would depend on how the data is being used and what each agency\u0026rsquo;s strategic goals are.) Thus, one of the hallmarks of the Agency of the Future will be project-based collaboration between the agency\u0026rsquo;s program leaders, its professional staff, and its analytic team(s).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eImprove data transparency.\u003c/strong\u003e Making data more transparent to providers, consumers, and others can strengthen performance management, enable continuous learning, and achieve other strategic goals. For example, Arizona\u0026rsquo;s Health Plan Report Cards make MCOs\u0026rsquo; quality performance and customer satisfaction scores available to consumers, enabling more informed consumer choice.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote15\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e15\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote15\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e15.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eArizona Health Care Cost Containment System website. Health plan report card.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003eReleasing physician performance data publicly can alter physician behavior even in the absence of financial incentives: once New York began publishing providers\u0026rsquo; mortality and complication rates after cardiac bypass surgery, risk-adjusted mortality declined 41%.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote16\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e16\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote16\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e16.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eHannan EL et al. New York State\u0026rsquo;s cardiac surgery reporting system: Four years later. \u003cem\u003eAnnals of Thoracic Surgery. \u003c/em\u003e1994;58(6):1852-7.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Public sharing of performance data also can help to avoid duplication, fraud, waste, and abuse, and to increase accountability for Medicaid agencies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild organizational capabilities and health\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr /\u003e\nOrganizational health lays the foundation for achieving any organization\u0026rsquo;s aspirations. Building new capabilities will likely require investments\u0026mdash;both financial and nonfinancial. While all investments must be made carefully, we have found that leaders who focus on organizational health using a deliberative approach usually deliver more value to their beneficiaries, taxpayers, and other stakeholders than those who do not. Furthermore, our cross-industry studies have shown that organi­zations that choose to focus on health typically see improvement quickly (on average, an 18% improvement in earnings within one year\u003ca rel=\"#footnote17\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e17\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote17\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e17.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eKeller S, Price C. \u003cem\u003eBeyond Performance: How Great Organizations Build Ultimate Competitive Advantage.\u003c/em\u003e 2011. (In this book, earnings were measured as EBITA.)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e). Key activities Medicaid agencies should focus on to achieve these goals include: Invest in organization design and health. Building and maintaining organizational health is vital for ensuring sustainable change. Agencies should regularly assess their health across the range of dimensions, including the organization\u0026rsquo;s aspirations, leadership, strategy, culture and values, funding, level of innovation, and other dimensions (Exhibit 5).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e[[Exhibit Exhibit_5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGood organizational design supports good organ­izational health. However, different agencies will need different designs, depending on several factors. For example, does the agency want to lead in shaping its state\u0026rsquo;s healthcare market\u0026mdash; or play a subordinate role? How has it opted to integrate its special needs efforts with its broader programs? What are its key priorities?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEnhance IT value assurance and delivery capabilities.\u003c/strong\u003e Not long ago, McKinsey and the University of Oxford collaborated to assess the performance of several thousand IT projects.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote18\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e18\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote18\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e18.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eBloch M, Blumberg S, Laartz J. Delivering large-scale IT projects on time, on budget, and on value. \u003cem\u003eFinancial Times.\u003c/em\u003e August 21, 2012.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The study uncovered several common themes that can help managers anticipate potential overruns in a project\u0026rsquo;s total cost and schedule (e.g., IT projects are often unable to recover from early schedule slips or overruns). Medicaid agencies should be cognizant of the widespread challenges to successful IT upgrades and transformation projects so they can prioritize the ones that will be most meaningful and also minimize risk.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eStrengthen talent management.\u003c/strong\u003e The more ambitious the agenda, the more critical it is that Medicaid agencies look to develop strong, end-to-end talent capabilities\u0026mdash;including the ability to attract, develop, deploy, reward, and retain top talent. A growing number of studies suggest that talent constraints at Medicaid agencies can be a barrier to good performance and a reason why some of the agencies underperform comparable organizations.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote19\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e19\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote19\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e19.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eNational Association of State Medicaid Directors. \u003cem\u003eState Medicaid Operations Survey: Second Annual Survey of Medicaid Directors.\u003c/em\u003e February 2014.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003ca rel=\"#footnote20\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e20\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote20\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e20.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eMedicaid and CHIP Payment and Access Commission. \u003cem\u003eReport to Congress on Medicaid and CHIP.\u003c/em\u003e March 2016.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e A particular problem is that the current average tenure of a Medicaid director is less than two years.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote21\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e21\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote21\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e21.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eThe average tenure fluctuates over time but was reported to be 23 months by the National Asso­ciation of Medicaid Directors in November 2016.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Agencies should therefore consider what they can do to increase the tenure of talented leaders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOptimize build vs. buy.\u003c/strong\u003e Increasingly, Medicaid leaders will need to make informed decisions about what to keep in-house and what it could outsource. This decision is particularly critical given that most agencies are making greater use of managed care, implementing value-based purchasing at scale, and/or replacing the business information system platforms they use for eligibility determinations, claims processing, and provider management. In our experience, certain activities\u0026mdash;e.g., policy recommendations\u0026mdash;must be retained by the agencies; other activities would best be retained in-house.\u003ca rel=\"#footnote22\" onclick=\"return false;\" class=\"link-footnote\" href=\"#\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e22\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" id=\"footnote22\" class=\"tooltip\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e22.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003eIn the case of infrastructure decisions, for example, internal infrastructure enables agility.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e However, other areas (e.g., member interactions) may be more efficiently handled if outsourced or delivered through a hybrid model. Among the factors agencies should consider when contemplating out­sourcing are strategic priorities, the managed care landscape, existing talent, and the availability of high-quality vendors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"text-align: center;\"\u003e* * *\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMedicaid has become the largest-ever ex­periment in federalism, as well as the largest centrally managed program in most states. Thus, many aspects of the program\u0026rsquo;s nature and scale are unprecedented. As a result, all Medicaid leaders will have to innovate to find the best practices that will allow them to steer their agencies forward. The need to innovate will be felt especially strongly by those who aspire to lead the Medicaid Agencies of the Future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe authors wish to thank Anne Conlin, Brian Latko, Pamela Sedmak, Penny Thompson, and Bryony Winn for their contributions to this article.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca
